fields.author: jayvdb

fields.body:
.. but closed issues/prs is empty ..

I see that https://deploy-preview-18--coala-gh-board.netlify.com/issues.json does include closed & merged items , so the graphql isnt the problem.
However there is only 1577 items in the JSON.  The number should be much higher.
According to https://developer.github.com/v4/guides/resource-limitations/ , the last: 100 is as high as it goes, and it means multiple GraphQL requests will be needed per repo, or the pre-fetcher may need to revert to using the REST API for the larger repos.
What is very nice about the GraphQL approach is that it works much better on PRs, which do not have a token.

fields.body:
@gautam1858 Pls, read the  commit guidelines carefully. Your shortlog, and your commit message do not correspond to the format specified.
Checklist specifically tells you to go through the commit guidelines, but you seem to have skipped that part altogether.
You're commit message should be something like this:
Review.rst: Typo Github->GitHub
Closes #5512
This format makes sure, that the issue is closed automatically when the pull request is merged. Filename is important because when you see your repository, it displays you're last commit in that directory, and it's much easier to know where the change was made when the filename is specified in the commit shortlog.
Please update your PR, and DO NOT FORGET TO SQUASH YOU'RE COMMITS into one. If you have trouble squashing commits, let me know.

fields.author: SubbulakshmiRS

fields.body:
max_file_length defines a rule for a hard physical line count maximum.
The LineCountBear would implement this taste by detecting files which exceed it, and producing an error.  That bear is a detection bear, not a fixing/suggestion bear.
We do not have any bear which attempts to fix files which exceed a maximum line count.  That would be difficult.
We do not have any bear which attempts to fix files which have insufficient line count.  However this is more feasible to implement.  We could have a bear which automatically fixed a minimum line count for Python, by automatically adding a dummy docstring.  It would also be possible to fix it for any scripting language by adding a 'hashbang', but that would be dumb as the otherwise empty file probably isn't runnable.

fields.author: ksdme

fields.body:
Hiya @shikharvaish28, thanks for reviewing.
We now have a template for creating the .gitignore, at https://gitlab.com/coala/mobans/blob/master/templates/gitignore.jj2 .
It pulls in a bunch of rules from https://github.com/github/gitignore .
The same template is being used on all of our repos, so that they are always in sync, and being updated whenever new rules are added to https://github.com/github/gitignore .
This also means that individual additions in each repo are no longer desirable; instead an addition needs to be proposed at https://github.com/github/gitignore , where they will be reviewed carefully and will benefit more people; when accepted, the change will flow through to our repos.

@kriti21
If nothing else, then the first point that I'd question is why does the assertion in GitCommitBear get a 'HEAD commit information'
while you are checking for the CommitResult Object in the VCSCommitBearTests
I know that you are using the same function of self.run_uut which was meant to only return messages,
But checking if the hidden result was generated or not is of no use in the GitCommitBear, either don't check it at all, (using some approach as described in my previous comment) or check the whole commit object like what would be done in the VCSCommitResult (both of them should be done imo, i.e don't check for the hidden results in the existing tests, so they won't change, and make another class to check for the hidden results)
As for the main logic, I'd recommended previously as well to have a look over generators,
The for loop that I had written as an example was simply to illustrate the point why the tests weren't being executed, I expected you to read up a little more on that and use the appropriate things
What would be apt would be using a yield from IMO
I hope I haven't got things wrong here and am clearer now 😅

fields.body:
we need to refine the list of newcomers to only those who should be in our newcomers system. there are too many people in newcomers who are doing nothing, going nowhere, not worth tracking.
Creating the filtered list of newcomers can be done weekly or nightly as a separate process, hosted on webservices (or your fake version atm), and produces a much smaller list of people. Then community repo gets that list, and only fetches data about them
"newcomers active in the last three months" could be a simple algorithm to start with
The hard part is defining 'active' -- MRs updated could be a bot, but the newcomer has long disappeared, so we should exclude those bot actions. I'm not sure if we have a better way of identifying activity... ?

fields.diff:
@@ -1,3 +1,44 @@
+What is Docker ?
+================
+
+Docker is a tool designed to make it easier to create, deploy, and run
+applications by using containers. Containers allow a developer to package
+up an application with all of the parts it needs, like libraries and other
+dependencies, and ship it all out as a single package.
+
+With the help of containers, the developer can rest assured that
+the application will run on other machine regardless of any
+customized settings that machine might have that could differ from the
+machine used for writing and testing the code.
+
+Unlike a virtual machine, rather than creating a whole virtual operating
+system, Docker allows applications to use the same kernel as the system
+that they're running on and only requires applications be shipped
+with things not already running on the host computer. This gives a
+significant performance boost and reduces the size of the application.

fields.body:
put all of this into two function.
The first function should be a HTML unaware utility function which takes a timestamp and ago value, and returns the timestring.
The function second should be a function which is given two HTML element objects, one for the time and the other for ago, and this section function would call the first function to get the computed value and would put that value into the ago element.
Optionally add a third function which takes no arguments, fetches the desired elements, and calls the second function.
The second or third function should be invoked from inside the HTML ; worse case, use body.onload to invoke it.

fields.body: Discussion in gitter regarding this. It messes up the gitter formatting to limit lines to 80 characters.
fields.diff:
@@ -0,0 +1 @@
+We use bug prediction in coala which relies on the `Fixes` keyword in commit messages. To get good results from that we need to use `Closes` for normal issues instead of `Fixes` which should only be used for real bugs. (See also [the commit message docs](https://coala.io/commit).) To change your message you just use `git commit --amend` and then `git push --force` the new commit to replace the old one.

fields.diff:
@@ -0,0 +1,27 @@
+import os
+import requests
+
+
+def get_logo():
+    # Obtain the org name from the Travis environment variables
+    org_name = os.environ['TRAVIS_REPO_SLUG'].split('/')[0]
+
+    image_url_short_max_res = 'http://github.com/%s.png' % (org_name)
+
+    # Follow the redirect to the page containing the image and
+    # store it in the response variable
+    response_max_res = requests.get(image_url_short_max_res)
+
+    # Write the image to a file and save
+    image = open('images/org_logo.png', 'wb')
+    image.write(response_max_res.content)
+    image.close()
+
+    # Run the same code again but download a 16x16 version for favicon
+    image_url_short_favicon = 'http://github.com/%s.png?size=16' % (org_name)
+
+    response_favicon = requests.get(image_url_short_favicon)
+
+    image = open('favicon.png', 'wb')

-# Create your models here.
+from django.db import models
+
+
+class Students(models.Model):
+    student_id = models.IntegerField(default=0, primary_key=True)
+    student_name = models.CharField(max_length=100, default='')
+    program_year = models.ForeignKey('ProgramYear', null=True)
+
+    def __str__(self):
+        return self.student_name
+
+class Organizations(models.Model):
+    org_id = models.IntegerField(default=0, primary_key=True)
+    org_name = models.CharField(max_length=100, default='')
+    org_logo = models.ImageField(upload_to='', blank=True, default='')
+    org_url = models.URLField(default='', blank=True)
+    org_summary = models.TextField(max_length=300, default='')
+    students = models.ManyToManyField(Students)
+
+    def __str__(self):
+        return self.org_name
+
+class Tasks(models.Model):
+    name = models.CharField(max_length=200, default='')
+    description = models.TextField(max_length=500, default='')
+    status = models.IntegerField(default=1)
+    max_instances = models.IntegerField(default=1)
+    mentors = models.ManyToManyField('Mentors')
+    tags = models.ManyToManyField('Tags')
+    is_beginner = models.BooleanField(default=False)
+    categories = models.ManyToManyField('Categories')
+    time_to_complete_in_days = models.IntegerField(default=3)
+    external_url = models.URLField()
+    private_metadata = models.CharField(max_length=80, default='')
+    last_modified = models.DateField()
+    _orgs = models.ForeignKey(Organizations)
+
+    def __str__(self):
+        return self.name
+
+class TaskInstance(models.Model):
+    task_definition_name = models.ForeignKey(Tasks)
+    student_display_name = models.ForeignKey(Students)
+    organization_name = models.ForeignKey(Organizations)
+    status = models.IntegerField()
+    completion_date = models.DateField()
+    deadline = models.DateField()
+    modified = models.DateField()
+
+class ProgramYear(models.Model):
+    start_date = models.DateField()
+    last_date = models.DateField()
+
+class Mentors(models.Model):
+    mentors_email_id = models.EmailField(default='')

fields.body: You could rather rename these fields to task, student and organization. Because a ForeignKey attribute actually only holds the primary key of the related members. Check the docs here for more on its internal representation.

+import requests
+import json
+import datetime
+from dateutil import parser, relativedelta
+
+issuesurl = "https://coala.github.io/gh-board/issues.json"
+today = datetime.datetime.today()
+
+def diff_month(d1, d2):
+	return (d1.year - d2.year) * 12 + d1.month - d2.month
+
+def diff_week(d1, d2):
+	monday1 = (d1 - datetime.timedelta(days=d1.weekday()))
+	monday2 = (d2 - datetime.timedelta(days=d2.weekday()))
+	return (monday1 - monday2).days / 7

@@ -0,0 +1,61 @@
+import os
+import os.path
+
+from git.config import GitConfigParser
+import giturlparse
+
+REPO_DIR = os.path.join(
+    os.path.dirname(__file__),
+    '..',
+)
+GIT_CONFIG = os.path.join(
+    REPO_DIR,
+    '.git',
+    'config',
+)
+
+_config = None
+
+
+def get_config():
+    global _config
+    if not _config:
+        _config = GitConfigParser(GIT_CONFIG)
+    return _config
+
+
+def get_config_remote(name='origin'):
+    config = get_config()
+
+    print(config.sections())
+
+    has_remote = False
+
+    for key in config.sections():
+        if key == 'remote "%s"' % name:
+            return config.items(key)
+        elif key.startswith('remote'):
+            has_remote = True
+
+    if has_remote:
+        raise KeyError('No git remote called "%s"' % name)
+
+    raise KeyError('No git remotes found')
+
+
+def get_remote_url():
+    url = os.environ.get('REPOSITORY_URL')
+    if not url:
+        remote = get_config_remote()
+        url = remote[0][1]
+
+    try:
+        url = giturlparse.parse(url)
+    except Exception:
+        url = giturlparse.parse(url + '.git')

fields.body:
I think we need to use an existing django app or library to provide the data fields, and thus also hold the data.
https://djangopackages.org/grids/g/calendar/ shows the main options.
django-scheduler looks like it has the most features built in, while django-eventtools looks like the most raw & re-usable with fewer features.
Assuming django-eventtools is our best option, we would need a custom GsocEvent(BaseEvent) and GsocOccurrence(BaseOccurrence), and the Program model would then need to have either

an array of GsocOccurrence , and all of these start/end are pushed into it as events with the event name derived from the prefix (e.g. org_signup_open -> title="Org signup open")
fields for each event, like org_signup_open = GsocOccurrence()

the later feels like the better option, at least initially.

+

+
+    ``cli`` is an internally reserved section name. All of its settings
+    are implicitly inherited to every other section by default. It is
+    because of this implicit inheritance feature that we are adviced to
+    rename the ``cli`` section to something else. Doing so will save us
+    from having unexpected values of ``cli`` being implicitly inherited
+    into our sections. We suggest that you change its name to ``all``.

+import sys
+import json
+import requests
+import xmltodict
+from openhub.models import MostCommit, MostRecentCommit, AffiliatedCommitter
+from django.core.management.base import BaseCommand
+from community.git import get_owner
+from openhub.oh_token import OH_TOKEN
+
+
+org_name = get_owner()
+class Command(BaseCommand):
+    def import_data(self, affiliator):
+        org = org_name
+        name = affiliator.get('name', None)
+        kudos = affiliator.get('kudos', None)
+        level = affiliator.get('level', None)
+        project1 = affiliator.get('most_commits', None).get('project')
+        commits = affiliator.get('most_commits', None).get('commits', None)
+        project2 = affiliator.get('most_recent_commit', None).get('project', None)
+        date = affiliator.get('most_recent_commit', None).get('date', None)
+
+        try:
+            cr1, create1 = MostCommit.objects.get_or_create(
+                project1 = project1,
+                commits = commits
+                )
+            if create1:
+                cr1.save()
+            cr2, create2 = MostRecentCommit.objects.get_or_create(
+                project2 = project2,
+                date = date
+                )
+            if create2:
+                cr2.save()
+            c, created = AffiliatedCommitter.objects.get_or_create(
+                name = name,
+                org = org,
+                kudos = kudos,
+                level = level,
+                most_commits = cr1,
+                most_recent_commit = cr2
+                )
+            if created:
+                c.save()
+                print ("\nAffiliatedCommitter, {}, has been saved.".format(c))

+import time
+import json
+
+from github import Github
+from dateutil.parser import parse
+from datetime import date
+from django.http import HttpResponse
+from gci.config import get_api_key
+
+
+def run(issue1):
+    issues_number_list = []
+    for j in issue1:
+        issue_no = j.number
+        events = j.get_events()
+        myevent = []
+        data = []
+        for i in events:
+            myevent.append(str(i.event))
+        for i in events:
+            if i.commit_id is not None:
+                data.append(str(i.created_at))
+        for i, myevents in reversed(list(enumerate(myevent))):
+            if myevents == 'unassigned':
+                break
+            elif myevents == 'assigned':
+                a = events[i].created_at
+                c = (date.fromtimestamp(time.time()) - a.date()).days
+                if c >= 60:  # for checking assigned duration
+
+                    mydata = list(reversed(data))
+                    if len(mydata) != 0:
+                        commit1 = parse(mydata[0])
+                        calculated_days = (date.fromtimestamp(
+                            time.time()) - commit1.date()).days
+                        if calculated_days >= 60:
+                            # for checking last commit update
+                            issues_number_list.append(issue_no)
+                    else:
+                        issues_number_list.append(issue_no)
+                break
+    return issues_number_list
+
+

fields.diff:
@@ -0,0 +1,130 @@
+NextGen-Core
+============
+
+This document provides a brief overview of coala's NextGen-Core.
+coala's NextGen-Core comes with the promise of eliminating the dependencies
+amongst bears (by removing the queuing machanism) and a better performance
+(by utilising asynchronous I/O and process pool).
+
+What has changed?
+-----------------
+
+``Global Bears`` are now called ``Project Bears`` and ``Local Bears`` are
+now known as ``File Bears``. Both the ``ProjectBear`` and the ``FileBear``
+classes inherit from the base class ``Bear.py``.
+
+- **ProjectBears:** Performs analysis on the whole codebase and does
+not parallelize tasks. All the bears GlobalBears formerly known as will now
+inherit from this class.
+
+- **FileBears:** Performs analysis on the files provided by the user
+and parallelizes tasks for each give file. All the bears formerly known as
+LocalBears will now inherit from this class.
+
+What is new?
+------------
+
+The following new features have been installed in the NextGen-Core:
+
+- New bear type: ``DependencyBear``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+
+DependencyBear
+--------------
+
+The handling of bear dependencies by the old core wasn't effective. The
+old core used a queuing mechanism to communicate betweeen bear runs which
+which led to problems of a GlobalBear not running if any one of its
+dependencies (a local bear) terminated. The NextGen-Core does away with
+that by introducing a ``DependencyBear``.
+
+This bear serves as a base class parallelizes tasks for each dependency
+result. A bear dependent on other bears can specify its dependencies in
+``BEAR_DEPS``. For example there are two bears ``Foo`` and ``Bar``
+and bear ``Bar`` depends on ``Foo``. This can be written as
+
+::
+
+    class BarBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FooBear}
+
+Multiple bears can be included as a dependency of a bear in the BEAR_DEPS
+field. The results of the dependency bears are saved in a dictionary
+called ``_dependency_results`` which is initialized in the ``__init()__``
+method of the class ``Bear.py`` and can be accessed using the method
+``dependency_results()`` also belonging to the same class.
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+------------------------------------------
+
+A bear might depend on mutilple bears before its execution can begin.
+``Bear.BEAR_DEPS`` is just a collection (a set) of classes (Bear classes) that
+need to be executed before that bear can run. Once all these dependencies
+(Bears) have ran their results are passed into ``self.dependency_results``.
+The results are in the form of a dictionary with the types of the bears and
+their corresponding results (in the form of a list) as *Key-Value* pairs.
+From the previous example if we try to access the BEAR_DEPS of the ``BarBear``
+we will get the following result.
+
+::
+
+    import BarBear
+
+    >>> BarBear.BEAR_DEPS
+    {<class 'coalib.core.Bear.FooBear'>}
+
+In the `__init__()` method of the class ``Bear.py`` the dependencies specified
+in the ``BEAR_DEPS`` are copied to every instance of a Bear run using
+``self.BEAR_DEPS = set(self.BEAR_DEPS)`` which makes runtime modifications
+are possible.
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A bear might have some external dependencies that need to be installed before
+the bear can run any analysis. The ``REQUIREMENTS`` field (a set) contains
+instances of the ``PackageRequirement`` class from the coala's
+``dependency_management`` module. For example.
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PackageRequirement import (
+    ...     PackageRequirement)
+    >>> class BarBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {
+    ...         PackageRequirement('pip', 'coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+If the bear uses requirements from a package manager then we can use the
+subclass of the ``PackageRequirement`` class for that package manager. For
+example in case of a pip requirement do the following:
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PipRequirement import (
+    ...     PipRequirement)
+    >>> class FooBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {PipRequirement('coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+The ``check_prerequisites()`` method in ``Bear.py`` is responsible for
+checking whether all the required packages are installed. If not then
+a runtime exception is raised.

+NextGen-Core
+============
+
+This document provides a brief overview of coala's NextGen-Core.
+coala's NextGen-Core comes with the promise of eliminating the dependencies
+amongst bears (by removing the queuing machanism) and a better performance
+(by utilising asynchronous I/O and process pool).
+
+What has changed?
+-----------------
+
+``Global Bears`` are now called ``Project Bears`` and ``Local Bears`` are
+now known as ``File Bears``. Both the ``ProjectBear`` and the ``FileBear``
+classes inherit from the base class ``coalib.core.Bear.py``.
+
+- **ProjectBears:** Performs analysis on the whole codebase and does
+not parallelize tasks. All the bears formerly known as GlobalBears will now
+inherit from this class.
+
+- **FileBears:** Performs analysis on the files provided by the user
+and parallelizes tasks for each give file. All the bears formerly known as
+LocalBears will now inherit from this class.
+
+What is new?
+------------
+
+The following new features have been installed in the NextGen-Core:
+
+- New bear type: ``DependencyBear``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+
+DependencyBear
+--------------
+
+The handling of bear dependencies by the old core wasn't effective. The
+old core used a queuing mechanism to communicate betweeen bear runs which
+led to problems of a GlobalBear not running if any one of its
+dependencies (a local bear) terminated. The NextGen-Core does away with
+that by introducing a ``DependencyBear``.
+
+This bear serves as a base class parallelizes tasks for each dependency
+result. A bear dependent on other bears can specify its dependencies in
+``BEAR_DEPS``. For example there are two bears ``Foo`` and ``Bar``
+and bear ``Bar`` depends on ``Foo``. This can be written as
+
+::
+
+    class BarBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FooBear}
+
+Multiple bears can be included as a dependency of a bear in the BEAR_DEPS
+field. The results of the dependency bears are saved in a dictionary
+called ``_dependency_results`` which is initialized in the ``__init()__``
+method of the class ``Bear.py`` and can be accessed using the method
+``dependency_results()`` also belonging to the same class.
+
+Writing A Dependency Bear
+-------------------------
+
+Lets consider a bear to be dependent on a project bear ``Fizz`` and a file bear
+``Buzz`` then the corresponding DependencyBear lets call it ``FizzBuzz`` will
+look like the following:

+
+    class FizzBuzzBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FizzBear, BuzzBear}
+
+        def analyze(self, dependency_bear, dependency_result, a_number=100):

@@ -0,0 +1,198 @@
+NextGen-Core
+============
+
+This document provides a brief overview of coala's NextGen-Core.
+coala's NextGen-Core comes with the promise of eliminating the dependencies
+amongst bears (by removing the queuing machanism) and a better performance
+(by utilising asynchronous I/O and process pool).
+
+What has changed?
+-----------------
+
+``Global Bears`` are now called ``Project Bears`` and ``Local Bears`` are
+now known as ``File Bears``. Both the ``ProjectBear`` and the ``FileBear``
+classes inherit from the base class ``coalib.core.Bear.py``.
+
+- **ProjectBears:** Performs analysis on the whole codebase and does
+not parallelize tasks. All the bears formerly known as GlobalBears will now
+inherit from this class.
+
+- **FileBears:** Performs analysis on the files provided by the user
+and parallelizes tasks for each give file. All the bears formerly known as
+LocalBears will now inherit from this class.
+
+What is new?
+------------
+
+The following new features have been installed in the NextGen-Core:
+
+- New bear type: ``DependencyBear``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+
+DependencyBear
+--------------
+
+The handling of bear dependencies by the old core wasn't effective. The
+old core used a queuing mechanism to communicate betweeen bear runs which
+led to problems of a GlobalBear not running if any one of its
+dependencies (a local bear) terminated. The NextGen-Core does away with
+that by introducing a ``DependencyBear``.
+
+This bear serves as a base class parallelizes tasks for each dependency
+result. A bear dependent on other bears can specify its dependencies in
+``BEAR_DEPS``. For example there are two bears ``Foo`` and ``Bar``
+and bear ``Bar`` depends on ``Foo``. This can be written as
+
+::
+
+    class BarBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FooBear}
+
+Multiple bears can be included as a dependency of a bear in the BEAR_DEPS
+field. The results of the dependency bears are saved in a dictionary
+called ``_dependency_results`` which is initialized in the ``__init()__``
+method of the class ``Bear.py`` and can be accessed using the method
+``dependency_results()`` also belonging to the same class.
+
+Writing A Dependency Bear
+-------------------------
+
+Lets consider a bear to be dependent on a project bear ``Fizz`` and a file bear
+``Buzz`` then the corresponding DependencyBear lets call it ``FizzBuzz`` will
+look like the following:
+
+::
+
+    class FizzBuzzBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FizzBear, BuzzBear}
+
+        def analyze(self, dependency_bear, dependency_result, a_number=100):
+            yield '{} ({}) - {}'.format(
+                dependency_bear.name, a_number, dependency_result)
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+------------------------------------------
+
+A bear might depend on mutilple bears before its execution can begin.
+``Bear.BEAR_DEPS`` is just a collection (a set) of classes (Bear classes) that
+need to be executed before that bear can run. Once all these dependencies
+(Bears) have ran their results are passed into ``self.dependency_results``.
+The results are in the form of a dictionary with the types of the bears and
+their corresponding results (in the form of a list) as *Key-Value* pairs.
+From the previous example if we try to access the BEAR_DEPS of the ``BarBear``
+we will get the result ``{<class 'coalib.core.Bear.FooBear'>}``.
+
+In the `__init__()` method of the class ``Bear.py`` the dependencies specified
+in the ``BEAR_DEPS`` are copied to every instance of a Bear run using
+``self.BEAR_DEPS = set(self.BEAR_DEPS)`` which makes runtime modifications
+are possible.
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A bear might have some external dependencies that need to be installed before
+the bear can run any analysis. The ``REQUIREMENTS`` field (a set) contains
+instances of the ``PackageRequirement`` class from the coala's
+``dependency_management`` module. For example.
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PackageRequirement import (
+    ...     PackageRequirement)
+    >>> from coalib.core.Bear import Bear
+    ...
+    >>> class BarBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {
+    ...         PackageRequirement('pip', 'coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+If the bear uses requirements from a package manager then we can use the
+subclass of the ``PackageRequirement`` class for that package manager. For
+example in case of a pip requirement do the following:
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PipRequirement import (
+    ...     PipRequirement)
+    >>> class FooBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {PipRequirement('coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+
+Override bears and define task scheduling
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A nextgen bear has to have the following functions to perform analysis
+- ``generate_tasks``: This method is a part of the parent ``Bear.py`` class
+and returns tuples containing the positional arguments as a tuple and the
+keyword arguments in the form of a dict. These are actually the task objects
+that are scheduled and executed by the core. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+- ``analyze``: This method contains the code that performs the actual code
+analysis routine that that bear is used for. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+
+How to use `Core.run`
+--------------------
+
+The `run(bears, result_callback, cache=None, executor=None)` method in `Core.PY`

+This document provides a brief overview of coala's NextGen-Core.

+amongst bears (by removing the queuing machanism) and a better performance
+(by utilising asynchronous I/O and process pool).

+-----------------

+------------

+        BEAR_DEPS = {FooBear}

+field. The results of the dependency bears are saved in a dictionary
+called ``_dependency_results`` which is initialized in the ``__init()__``
+method of the class ``Bear.py`` and can be accessed using the method
+``dependency_results()`` also belonging to the same class.
+

+-------------------------
+
+Lets consider a bear to be dependent on a project bear ``Fizz`` and a file bear
+``Buzz`` then the corresponding DependencyBear lets call it ``FizzBuzz`` will
+look like the following:
+
+::
+
+    class FizzBuzzBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FizzBear, BuzzBear}
+
+        def analyze(self, dependency_bear, dependency_result, a_number=100):
+            yield '{} ({}) - {}'.format(
+                dependency_bear.name, a_number, dependency_result)
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+------------------------------------------
+
+A bear might depend on mutilple bears before its execution can begin.
+``Bear.BEAR_DEPS`` is just a collection (a set) of classes (Bear classes) that
+need to be executed before that bear can run. Once all these dependencies
+(Bears) have ran their results are passed into ``self.dependency_results``.
+The results are in the form of a dictionary with the types of the bears and
+their corresponding results (in the form of a list) as *Key-Value* pairs.
+From the previous example if we try to access the BEAR_DEPS of the ``BarBear``
+we will get the result ``{<class 'coalib.core.Bear.FooBear'>}``.
+
+In the `__init__()` method of the class ``Bear.py`` the dependencies specified
+in the ``BEAR_DEPS`` are copied to every instance of a Bear run using
+``self.BEAR_DEPS = set(self.BEAR_DEPS)`` which makes runtime modifications
+are possible.
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A bear might have some external dependencies that need to be installed before
+the bear can run any analysis. The ``REQUIREMENTS`` field (a set) contains
+instances of the ``PackageRequirement`` class from the coala's
+``dependency_management`` module. For example.
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PackageRequirement import (
+    ...     PackageRequirement)
+    >>> from coalib.core.Bear import Bear
+    ...
+    >>> class BarBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {
+    ...         PackageRequirement('pip', 'coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+If the bear uses requirements from a package manager then we can use the
+subclass of the ``PackageRequirement`` class for that package manager. For
+example in case of a pip requirement do the following:
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PipRequirement import (
+    ...     PipRequirement)
+    >>> class FooBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {PipRequirement('coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+
+Override bears and define task scheduling
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A nextgen bear has to have the following functions to perform analysis
+- ``generate_tasks``: This method is a part of the parent ``Bear.py`` class
+and returns tuples containing the positional arguments as a tuple and the
+keyword arguments in the form of a dict. These are actually the task objects
+that are scheduled and executed by the core. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+- ``analyze``: This method contains the code that performs the actual code
+analysis routine that that bear is used for. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+
+How to use `Core.run`
+--------------------
+
+The `run(bears, result_callback, cache=None, executor=None)` method in `Core.PY`
+is used to instantiate a coala session with the parameters it receives and run
+it.
+- ``bears``: contains all the instances of bears to run.
+- ``result_callback``: a function that is called only when the results from
+the bears are available.
+- ``cache``: a cache used by bears to speed up runs.
+- ``executor``: a custom executor used to run the bears. By default
+``ProcessPoolExecutor`` is used.
+
+The new core comes with the following new additions:
+- **Dependency Resolution:** The ``initialize_dependencies`` method in
+``Core.py`` recieves the bears that are to be run and processes bear
+dependencies using a consumer based system so that each dependency bear has only
+one instance per section and file-dict. It returns a set of dependency bears
+along with those bears that don't have any dependencies or whose dependencies
+have been resolved(these are the ones that are scheduled to be run). The bears
+are resolved by traversing each edge of the dependency graph and instantiating
+dependency bears accordingly one per section. Before the bears are run we
+initialize the dependency tracking in the ``__init__`` method of the class
+``Session`` which is responsible for running coala sessions. The
+``dependency_tracker`` object is used while scheduling and cleaning up bears and
+also while finishing bear tasks.
+
+- **Task Scheduling:** The bears that have no dependencies or whose
+dependencies have been resolved, only their tasks will be scheduled for
+execution. Before exexuting any tasks the coala looks up the task in the cache.

+need to be executed before that bear can run. Once all these dependencies
+(Bears) have ran their results are passed into ``self.dependency_results``.
+The results are in the form of a dictionary with the types of the bears and
+their corresponding results (in the form of a list) as *Key-Value* pairs.
+From the previous example if we try to access the BEAR_DEPS of the ``BarBear``
+we will get the result ``{<class 'coalib.core.Bear.FooBear'>}``.
+
+In the `__init__()` method of the class ``Bear.py`` the dependencies specified
+in the ``BEAR_DEPS`` are copied to every instance of a Bear run using
+``self.BEAR_DEPS = set(self.BEAR_DEPS)`` which makes runtime modifications
+are possible.
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A bear might have some external dependencies that need to be installed before
+the bear can run any analysis. The ``REQUIREMENTS`` field (a set) contains
+instances of the ``PackageRequirement`` class from the coala's
+``dependency_management`` module. For example.
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PackageRequirement import (
+    ...     PackageRequirement)
+    >>> from coalib.core.Bear import Bear
+    ...
+    >>> class BarBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {
+    ...         PackageRequirement('pip', 'coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+If the bear uses requirements from a package manager then we can use the
+subclass of the ``PackageRequirement`` class for that package manager. For
+example in case of a pip requirement do the following:
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PipRequirement import (
+    ...     PipRequirement)
+    >>> class FooBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {PipRequirement('coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+
+Override bears and define task scheduling
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A nextgen bear has to have the following functions to perform analysis
+- ``generate_tasks``: This method is a part of the parent ``Bear.py`` class
+and returns tuples containing the positional arguments as a tuple and the
+keyword arguments in the form of a dict. These are actually the task objects
+that are scheduled and executed by the core. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+- ``analyze``: This method contains the code that performs the actual code
+analysis routine that that bear is used for. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+
+How to use `Core.run`
+--------------------
+
+The `run(bears, result_callback, cache=None, executor=None)` method in `Core.PY`
+is used to instantiate a coala session with the parameters it receives and run
+it.
+- ``bears``: contains all the instances of bears to run.
+- ``result_callback``: a function that is called only when the results from
+the bears are available.
+- ``cache``: a cache used by bears to speed up runs.
+- ``executor``: a custom executor used to run the bears. By default
+``ProcessPoolExecutor`` is used.
+
+The new core comes with the following new additions:
+- **Dependency Resolution:** The ``initialize_dependencies`` method in
+``Core.py`` recieves the bears that are to be run and processes bear
+dependencies using a consumer based system so that each dependency bear has only
+one instance per section and file-dict. It returns a set of dependency bears
+along with those bears that don't have any dependencies or whose dependencies
+have been resolved(these are the ones that are scheduled to be run). The bears
+are resolved by traversing each edge of the dependency graph and instantiating
+dependency bears accordingly one per section. Before the bears are run we
+initialize the dependency tracking in the ``__init__`` method of the class
+``Session`` which is responsible for running coala sessions. The
+``dependency_tracker`` object is used while scheduling and cleaning up bears and
+also while finishing bear tasks.
+
+- **Task Scheduling:** The bears that have no dependencies or whose
+dependencies have been resolved, only their tasks will be scheduled for
+execution. Before exexuting any tasks the coala looks up the task in the cache.
+In case of a hit the existing results that is stored in the cache for the
+corresponding task arguments is called using ``execute_task_with_cache``

@@ -0,0 +1,198 @@
+NextGen-Core
+============
+
+This document provides a brief overview of coala's NextGen-Core.
+coala's NextGen-Core comes with the promise of eliminating the dependencies
+amongst bears (by removing the queuing machanism) and a better performance
+(by utilising asynchronous I/O and process pool).
+
+What has changed?
+-----------------
+
+``Global Bears`` are now called ``Project Bears`` and ``Local Bears`` are
+now known as ``File Bears``. Both the ``ProjectBear`` and the ``FileBear``
+classes inherit from the base class ``coalib.core.Bear.py``.
+
+- **ProjectBears:** Performs analysis on the whole codebase and does
+not parallelize tasks. All the bears formerly known as GlobalBears will now
+inherit from this class.
+
+- **FileBears:** Performs analysis on the files provided by the user
+and parallelizes tasks for each give file. All the bears formerly known as
+LocalBears will now inherit from this class.
+
+What is new?
+------------
+
+The following new features have been installed in the NextGen-Core:
+
+- New bear type: ``DependencyBear``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+
+DependencyBear
+--------------
+
+The handling of bear dependencies by the old core wasn't effective. The
+old core used a queuing mechanism to communicate betweeen bear runs which
+led to problems of a GlobalBear not running if any one of its
+dependencies (a local bear) terminated. The NextGen-Core does away with
+that by introducing a ``DependencyBear``.
+
+This bear serves as a base class parallelizes tasks for each dependency
+result. A bear dependent on other bears can specify its dependencies in
+``BEAR_DEPS``. For example there are two bears ``Foo`` and ``Bar``
+and bear ``Bar`` depends on ``Foo``. This can be written as
+
+::
+
+    class BarBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FooBear}
+
+Multiple bears can be included as a dependency of a bear in the BEAR_DEPS
+field. The results of the dependency bears are saved in a dictionary
+called ``_dependency_results`` which is initialized in the ``__init()__``
+method of the class ``Bear.py`` and can be accessed using the method
+``dependency_results()`` also belonging to the same class.
+
+Writing A Dependency Bear
+-------------------------
+
+Lets consider a bear to be dependent on a project bear ``Fizz`` and a file bear
+``Buzz`` then the corresponding DependencyBear lets call it ``FizzBuzz`` will
+look like the following:
+
+::
+
+    class FizzBuzzBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FizzBear, BuzzBear}
+
+        def analyze(self, dependency_bear, dependency_result, a_number=100):
+            yield '{} ({}) - {}'.format(
+                dependency_bear.name, a_number, dependency_result)
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+------------------------------------------
+
+A bear might depend on mutilple bears before its execution can begin.
+``Bear.BEAR_DEPS`` is just a collection (a set) of classes (Bear classes) that
+need to be executed before that bear can run. Once all these dependencies
+(Bears) have ran their results are passed into ``self.dependency_results``.
+The results are in the form of a dictionary with the types of the bears and
+their corresponding results (in the form of a list) as *Key-Value* pairs.
+From the previous example if we try to access the BEAR_DEPS of the ``BarBear``
+we will get the result ``{<class 'coalib.core.Bear.FooBear'>}``.
+
+In the `__init__()` method of the class ``Bear.py`` the dependencies specified
+in the ``BEAR_DEPS`` are copied to every instance of a Bear run using
+``self.BEAR_DEPS = set(self.BEAR_DEPS)`` which makes runtime modifications
+are possible.
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A bear might have some external dependencies that need to be installed before
+the bear can run any analysis. The ``REQUIREMENTS`` field (a set) contains
+instances of the ``PackageRequirement`` class from the coala's
+``dependency_management`` module. For example.
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PackageRequirement import (
+    ...     PackageRequirement)
+    >>> from coalib.core.Bear import Bear
+    ...
+    >>> class BarBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {
+    ...         PackageRequirement('pip', 'coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+If the bear uses requirements from a package manager then we can use the
+subclass of the ``PackageRequirement`` class for that package manager. For
+example in case of a pip requirement do the following:
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PipRequirement import (
+    ...     PipRequirement)
+    >>> class FooBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {PipRequirement('coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+
+Override bears and define task scheduling
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A nextgen bear has to have the following functions to perform analysis
+- ``generate_tasks``: This method is a part of the parent ``Bear.py`` class
+and returns tuples containing the positional arguments as a tuple and the
+keyword arguments in the form of a dict. These are actually the task objects
+that are scheduled and executed by the core. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+- ``analyze``: This method contains the code that performs the actual code
+analysis routine that that bear is used for. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+
+How to use `Core.run`
+--------------------
+
+The `run(bears, result_callback, cache=None, executor=None)` method in `Core.PY`
+is used to instantiate a coala session with the parameters it receives and run
+it.
+- ``bears``: contains all the instances of bears to run.
+- ``result_callback``: a function that is called only when the results from
+the bears are available.
+- ``cache``: a cache used by bears to speed up runs.
+- ``executor``: a custom executor used to run the bears. By default
+``ProcessPoolExecutor`` is used.
+
+The new core comes with the following new additions:
+- **Dependency Resolution:** The ``initialize_dependencies`` method in
+``Core.py`` recieves the bears that are to be run and processes bear
+dependencies using a consumer based system so that each dependency bear has only
+one instance per section and file-dict. It returns a set of dependency bears
+along with those bears that don't have any dependencies or whose dependencies
+have been resolved(these are the ones that are scheduled to be run). The bears
+are resolved by traversing each edge of the dependency graph and instantiating
+dependency bears accordingly one per section. Before the bears are run we
+initialize the dependency tracking in the ``__init__`` method of the class
+``Session`` which is responsible for running coala sessions. The
+``dependency_tracker`` object is used while scheduling and cleaning up bears and
+also while finishing bear tasks.
+
+- **Task Scheduling:** The bears that have no dependencies or whose
+dependencies have been resolved, only their tasks will be scheduled for
+execution. Before exexuting any tasks the coala looks up the task in the cache.
+In case of a hit the existing results that is stored in the cache for the
+corresponding task arguments is called using ``execute_task_with_cache``
+method. In case of a miss or if coala is ran without a cache the bear task is
+executed. The bears without any running tasks are cleaned up from the state of
+an ongoing run by resolving its dependencies, scheduling dependent bears(if any)
+and removing the bear from the ``running_tasks`` dict. When a task belonging to
+a particular bear completes, then ``_finish_task`` method is responsible for
+checking whether the bear execution is complete and the result generated from
+the task have been returned. If any new tasks are to be scheduled then this
+method is responsible for doing so after the dependencies have been resolved.
+
+- **result_callback():** Each of the bears scheduled to run for a session have
+this callback function that is called when the results are available. It should
+have the following signature ``def result_callback(result)``.
+
+- **executors:** These are instances of the ``ProcessPoolExecutor`` class
+provided by the ``concurrent.futures`` module that is used to execute function
+calls asynchronously using a pool of processes. Custom ``executor`` instances
+can be passed to functions parameters to run the bears if not provided then a
+``ProcessPoolExecutor`` is used using maximum number of processors available on

+execution. Before exexuting any tasks the coala looks up the task in the cache.
+In case of a hit the existing results that is stored in the cache for the
+corresponding task arguments is called using ``execute_task_with_cache``
+method. In case of a miss or if coala is ran without a cache the bear task is
+executed. The bears without any running tasks are cleaned up from the state of
+an ongoing run by resolving its dependencies, scheduling dependent bears(if any)
+and removing the bear from the ``running_tasks`` dict. When a task belonging to
+a particular bear completes, then ``_finish_task`` method is responsible for
+checking whether the bear execution is complete and the result generated from
+the task have been returned. If any new tasks are to be scheduled then this
+method is responsible for doing so after the dependencies have been resolved.
+
+- **result_callback():** Each of the bears scheduled to run for a session have
+this callback function that is called when the results are available. It should
+have the following signature ``def result_callback(result)``.
+
+- **executors:** These are instances of the ``ProcessPoolExecutor`` class
+provided by the ``concurrent.futures`` module that is used to execute function
+calls asynchronously using a pool of processes. Custom ``executor`` instances
+can be passed to functions parameters to run the bears if not provided then a
+``ProcessPoolExecutor`` is used using maximum number of processors available on
+the machine.
+
+Caching
+-------
+
+The NextGen-Core's caching mechanism is based on task objects. Bears can offload
+tasks via `generate_tasks()` which get executed by a Python pool.
+Structure wise the cache is a dictionary-like-object with bear types
+and cache-tables as key value pairs. The cache-tables themselves are themselves
+dictionary-like-objects that map the hash values of the task objects (generated
+by ``PersistentHash.persistent_hash``) to the bear results.
+
+At the time of scheduling the bears, the core performs a cache lookup, if the
+parameters to ``execute_tasks()`` are the same as that of the previous run then

fields.diff:
@@ -0,0 +1,198 @@
+NextGen-Core
+============
+
+This document provides a brief overview of coala's NextGen-Core.
+coala's NextGen-Core comes with the promise of eliminating the dependencies
+amongst bears (by removing the queuing machanism) and a better performance
+(by utilising asynchronous I/O and process pool).
+
+What has changed?
+-----------------
+
+``Global Bears`` are now called ``Project Bears`` and ``Local Bears`` are
+now known as ``File Bears``. Both the ``ProjectBear`` and the ``FileBear``
+classes inherit from the base class ``coalib.core.Bear.py``.
+
+- **ProjectBears:** Performs analysis on the whole codebase and does
+not parallelize tasks. All the bears formerly known as GlobalBears will now
+inherit from this class.
+
+- **FileBears:** Performs analysis on the files provided by the user
+and parallelizes tasks for each give file. All the bears formerly known as
+LocalBears will now inherit from this class.
+
+What is new?
+------------
+
+The following new features have been installed in the NextGen-Core:
+
+- New bear type: ``DependencyBear``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+- Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+
+DependencyBear
+--------------
+
+The handling of bear dependencies by the old core wasn't effective. The
+old core used a queuing mechanism to communicate betweeen bear runs which
+led to problems of a GlobalBear not running if any one of its
+dependencies (a local bear) terminated. The NextGen-Core does away with
+that by introducing a ``DependencyBear``.
+
+This bear serves as a base class parallelizes tasks for each dependency
+result. A bear dependent on other bears can specify its dependencies in
+``BEAR_DEPS``. For example there are two bears ``Foo`` and ``Bar``
+and bear ``Bar`` depends on ``Foo``. This can be written as
+
+::
+
+    class BarBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FooBear}
+
+Multiple bears can be included as a dependency of a bear in the BEAR_DEPS
+field. The results of the dependency bears are saved in a dictionary
+called ``_dependency_results`` which is initialized in the ``__init()__``
+method of the class ``Bear.py`` and can be accessed using the method
+``dependency_results()`` also belonging to the same class.
+
+Writing A Dependency Bear
+-------------------------
+
+Lets consider a bear to be dependent on a project bear ``Fizz`` and a file bear
+``Buzz`` then the corresponding DependencyBear lets call it ``FizzBuzz`` will
+look like the following:
+
+::
+
+    class FizzBuzzBear(DependencyBear):
+        BEAR_DEPS = {FizzBear, BuzzBear}
+
+        def analyze(self, dependency_bear, dependency_result, a_number=100):
+            yield '{} ({}) - {}'.format(
+                dependency_bear.name, a_number, dependency_result)
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.BEAR_DEPS``
+------------------------------------------
+
+A bear might depend on mutilple bears before its execution can begin.
+``Bear.BEAR_DEPS`` is just a collection (a set) of classes (Bear classes) that
+need to be executed before that bear can run. Once all these dependencies
+(Bears) have ran their results are passed into ``self.dependency_results``.
+The results are in the form of a dictionary with the types of the bears and
+their corresponding results (in the form of a list) as *Key-Value* pairs.
+From the previous example if we try to access the BEAR_DEPS of the ``BarBear``
+we will get the result ``{<class 'coalib.core.Bear.FooBear'>}``.
+
+In the `__init__()` method of the class ``Bear.py`` the dependencies specified
+in the ``BEAR_DEPS`` are copied to every instance of a Bear run using
+``self.BEAR_DEPS = set(self.BEAR_DEPS)`` which makes runtime modifications
+are possible.
+
+Usage of instance-bound ``Bear.REQUIREMENTS``
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A bear might have some external dependencies that need to be installed before
+the bear can run any analysis. The ``REQUIREMENTS`` field (a set) contains
+instances of the ``PackageRequirement`` class from the coala's
+``dependency_management`` module. For example.
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PackageRequirement import (
+    ...     PackageRequirement)
+    >>> from coalib.core.Bear import Bear
+    ...
+    >>> class BarBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {
+    ...         PackageRequirement('pip', 'coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+If the bear uses requirements from a package manager then we can use the
+subclass of the ``PackageRequirement`` class for that package manager. For
+example in case of a pip requirement do the following:
+
+::
+
+    >>> from dependency_management.requirements.PipRequirement import (
+    ...     PipRequirement)
+    >>> class FooBear(Bear):
+    ...     REQUIREMENTS = {PipRequirement('coala_decorators', '0.2.1')}
+
+
+Override bears and define task scheduling
+-----------------------------------------
+
+A nextgen bear has to have the following functions to perform analysis
+- ``generate_tasks``: This method is a part of the parent ``Bear.py`` class
+and returns tuples containing the positional arguments as a tuple and the
+keyword arguments in the form of a dict. These are actually the task objects
+that are scheduled and executed by the core. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+- ``analyze``: This method contains the code that performs the actual code
+analysis routine that that bear is used for. Absence of this method raises
+``NotImplementedError``.
+
+How to use `Core.run`
+--------------------
+
+The `run(bears, result_callback, cache=None, executor=None)` method in `Core.PY`
+is used to instantiate a coala session with the parameters it receives and run
+it.
+- ``bears``: contains all the instances of bears to run.
+- ``result_callback``: a function that is called only when the results from
+the bears are available.
+- ``cache``: a cache used by bears to speed up runs.
+- ``executor``: a custom executor used to run the bears. By default
+``ProcessPoolExecutor`` is used.
+
+The new core comes with the following new additions:
+- **Dependency Resolution:** The ``initialize_dependencies`` method in
+``Core.py`` recieves the bears that are to be run and processes bear
+dependencies using a consumer based system so that each dependency bear has only
+one instance per section and file-dict. It returns a set of dependency bears
+along with those bears that don't have any dependencies or whose dependencies
+have been resolved(these are the ones that are scheduled to be run). The bears
+are resolved by traversing each edge of the dependency graph and instantiating
+dependency bears accordingly one per section. Before the bears are run we
+initialize the dependency tracking in the ``__init__`` method of the class
+``Session`` which is responsible for running coala sessions. The
+``dependency_tracker`` object is used while scheduling and cleaning up bears and
+also while finishing bear tasks.
+
+- **Task Scheduling:** The bears that have no dependencies or whose
+dependencies have been resolved, only their tasks will be scheduled for
+execution. Before exexuting any tasks the coala looks up the task in the cache.
+In case of a hit the existing results that is stored in the cache for the
+corresponding task arguments is called using ``execute_task_with_cache``
+method. In case of a miss or if coala is ran without a cache the bear task is
+executed. The bears without any running tasks are cleaned up from the state of
+an ongoing run by resolving its dependencies, scheduling dependent bears(if any)
+and removing the bear from the ``running_tasks`` dict. When a task belonging to
+a particular bear completes, then ``_finish_task`` method is responsible for
+checking whether the bear execution is complete and the result generated from
+the task have been returned. If any new tasks are to be scheduled then this
+method is responsible for doing so after the dependencies have been resolved.
+
+- **result_callback():** Each of the bears scheduled to run for a session have
+this callback function that is called when the results are available. It should
+have the following signature ``def result_callback(result)``.
+
+- **executors:** These are instances of the ``ProcessPoolExecutor`` class
+provided by the ``concurrent.futures`` module that is used to execute function
+calls asynchronously using a pool of processes. Custom ``executor`` instances
+can be passed to functions parameters to run the bears if not provided then a
+``ProcessPoolExecutor`` is used using maximum number of processors available on
+the machine.
+
+Caching
+-------
+
+The NextGen-Core's caching mechanism is based on task objects. Bears can offload
+tasks via `generate_tasks()` which get executed by a Python pool.
+Structure wise the cache is a dictionary-like-object with bear types
+and cache-tables as key value pairs. The cache-tables themselves are themselves

 - ``process_output_corrected``: Extracts results (with patches) by using a
   corrected version of the file processed.
 
-::
+  ::
 
     @linter(executable='my_tool',
-            use_stdout=True,
-            use_stderr=True)
+            use_stdout=True)
     class MyBear:
-        # Assuming the tool puts a corrected version of the file into stdout

+            yield from self.process_output_corrected(
+                                stdout, filename, file,
+                                diff_severity=RESULT_SEVERITY.NORMAL,
+                                diff_distance=2)
+
+  Here, the ``diff_distance`` parameter takes the number of unchanged lines
+  allowed in between two changed lines so they get yielded as a single diff.
+  If ``-1`` is given, every change will be yielded as an own diff.
+
+- ``process_output_unified_diff``: Extracts results (with patches) by processing
+  a unified diff.
+
+  ::
+
+      @linter(executable='my_tool',
+              use_stdout=True,
+              use_stderr=True)
+      class MyBear:
+          # Assuming the tool puts a unified diff into stdout
+          # and additional issue messages (that can't be fixed automatically)
+          # into stderr, let's combine both streams!
+          def process_output(self, output, filename, file):
+              # output is now a tuple, as we activated both, ``use_stdout`` and
+              # ``use_stderr``.
+              stdout, stderr = output
+              yield from self.process_output_unified_diff(
+                                stdout, filename, file)
+              regex = "(?P<message>.*)"
+              yield from self.process_output_regex(
+                                stderr, filename, file, regex)
+
+  In this case, ``stdout`` is the output from the executable (a string)
+  containing the unified diff for correction.

fields.body:
this is all the same as JavaScript ES6.
Create a separate issue about how to model Flow being a derivative of a specific JavaScript version, and get feedback from people involved in the language definitions, especially @userzimmermann .
A complication is that ES6 has backticks while other versions don't.
I doubt we model Python versions correctly yet, so JavaScript versions is going to be breaking new ground.

+from coalib.bearlib.languages.Language import Language
+
+
+@Language
+class Flow:
+    extensions = '.js'
+    comment_delimiter = '//'
+    multiline_comment_delimiters = {'/*': '*/'}
+    string_delimiters = {'"': '"', "'": "'"}
+    multiline_string_delimiters = {'`': '`'}

+from coalib.parsing.FilterHelper import (
+    apply_filter,
+    apply_filters,
+    is_valid_filter,
+    _filter_section_bears
+)
+from coalib.parsing.filters import available_filters
+from coalib.parsing.InvalidFilterException import InvalidFilterException
+from coalib.settings.ConfigurationGathering import get_all_bears
+
+
+class FilterHelperTest(unittest.TestCase):
+
+    def test_apply_filter_exception(self):
+        with self.assertRaises(InvalidFilterException) as exp:
+            apply_filter('unknown', ['args'])
+
+        message = str(exp.exception)
+        self.assertEqual("'unknown' is an invalid filter. Available filters: "
+                         + ', '.join(sorted(available_filters)), message)
+
+    def test_apply_filters_exception(self):
+        with self.assertRaises(InvalidFilterException) as exp:
+            apply_filters([['language', 'C', 'Python'],
+                           ['unknown', 'args']])
+
+        message = str(exp.exception)
+        self.assertEqual("'unknown' is an invalid filter. Available filters: "
+                         + ', '.join(sorted(available_filters)), message)
+
+    def test_is_valid_filter(self):
+        wrong_filter_result = is_valid_filter('check')
+        right_filter_result = is_valid_filter('can_detect')

+import unittest
+
+from coalib.parsing.FilterHelper import (
+    apply_filter,

+    _filter_section_bears
+)
+from coalib.parsing.filters import available_filters

+

+class FilterHelperTest(unittest.TestCase):
+
+    def test_apply_filter_exception(self):
+        with self.assertRaises(InvalidFilterException) as exp:
+            apply_filter('unknown', ['args'])
+
+        message = str(exp.exception)
+        self.assertEqual("'unknown' is an invalid filter. Available filters: "
+                         + ', '.join(sorted(available_filters)), message)
+

@@ -0,0 +1,77 @@
+Using coala-quickstart to Generate a coala Configuration File
+=============================================================
+
+This document aims to make people aware of this tool called
+coala-quickstart by providing a brief introduction about its features and how
+to use it, to quickly generate coala configuration files for your projects.
+
+What is coala-quickstart?
+-------------------------
+
+coala-quickstart is a cli tool that helps users to quickly get started with
+coala by generating a ``.coafile`` tailored for their project. The ``.coafile``
+is generated based on the questions answered by the users about their project.
+
+Features
+--------
+
+coala-quickstart offers the following features:
+
+- Out-of-the-box support for projects using various popular languages such as
+  C/C++, Python, JavaScript and many more with built-in check routines.
+- Automatic detection of languages used in your project.
+- Automatatically ignoring the files mentioned in the ``.gitignore`` of your
+  project's directory.
+- Automatic identification of bears that might be relevant for your project
+  based on the languages used.
+- A clean and simple interface with a well defined flow.
+
+Installation
+------------
+
+To install the latest stable version run:
+
+::
+
+    $ pip3 install coala-quickstart
+
+To install the latest development version run:
+
+::
+
+    $ pip3 install coala-quickstart --pre

+    provide coverage of Windows specific lines, and Travis/Circle
+    provide coverage of Unix specific lines. Thus, your test coverage
+    can 'pass' without reaching 100% .
fields.author: ishanSrt

fields.body:
The info that @ishanSrt is providing is also very important, as developers often forget to write tests, and that is typically why they will see test coverage not reach 100%.  But for that to happen, they wont have run pytest, because it will load the plugins mentioned in setup.cfg, which includes coverage, and it will fail locally if they havent written the tests yet.
The solution is not for the developer to add #pragma: no cover.  The code reviewer will usually reject that.  And soon we'll have CI automatically reject that, except in the most limited of cases.
Usually the correct solution is write some tests.

+from django.db import models
+
+
+class Participant(models.Model):
+    login = models.TextField(default=None, primary_key=True)
+    name = models.TextField(default=None, null=True)
+    score = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+    rank = models.IntegerField(default=None, null=True)
+
+    # ranking trend compared to last iteration
+    trend = models.IntegerField(default=None, null=True)
+
+    # time of latest action
+    last_active_at = models.DateTimeField(default=None, null=True)
+
+    # number of positive reactions received
+    pos_in = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # weighted positive reactions received
+    weighted_pos_in = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # number of positive reactions give away
+    pos_out = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # number of negative reactions received
+    neg_in = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # weighted negative reactions received
+    weighted_neg_in = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # number of negative reactions give away
+    neg_out = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # punishment points
+    punishment = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # weight factor
+    weight_factor = models.FloatField(default=0.1, null=True)
+
+    def __str__(self):
+        return 'Meta-reviewer: ' + self.login
+
+    class Meta:
+        ordering = ['rank']
+
+
+class Comment(models.Model):
+    id = models.TextField(default=None, primary_key=True)

fields.author: blazeu

fields.body:
I would like to hear more voice.
I have thought it for a while and tried finding some evidence to support my original idea. I did find some, very weak though.
As https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.0/topics/db/models/#automatic-primary-key-fields points out,
By default, Django gives each model the following field:

id = models.AutoField(primary_key=True)

Also, from https://github.com/django/django/blob/f1f4aeb22e7bc9b504f69f7cb111ac9bdedb5f1e/django/db/models/base.py#L1298-L1312 we can see that they allow the usage of id field as long as it has primary_key=True

+from django.db import models
+
+
+class Participant(models.Model):
+    login = models.TextField(default=None, primary_key=True)
+    name = models.TextField(default=None, null=True)
+    score = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+    rank = models.IntegerField(default=None, null=True)
+
+    # ranking trend compared to last iteration
+    trend = models.IntegerField(default=None, null=True)
+
+    # time of latest action

+
+    # number of positive reactions received
+    pos_in = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # weighted positive reactions received
+    weighted_pos_in = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # number of positive reactions give away
+    pos_out = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # number of negative reactions received
+    neg_in = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # weighted negative reactions received
+    weighted_neg_in = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # number of negative reactions give away
+    neg_out = models.IntegerField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # punishment points
+    punishment = models.FloatField(default=0, null=True)
+
+    # weight factor

+
+    def __str__(self):
+        return 'Meta-reviewer: ' + self.login
+
+    class Meta:
+        ordering = ['rank']
+
+
+class Comment(models.Model):
+    id = models.TextField(default=None, primary_key=True)

+from meta_review.models import Participant
+from django.shortcuts import render
+from django.db.models import Q
+
+
+def index(request):
+    participants = Participant.objects.all().exclude(
+        Q(pos_in=0),
+        Q(neg_in=0),
+        Q(pos_out=0),
+        Q(neg_out=0),
+        Q(punishment=0)
+    )
+    args = {'participants': participants}
+    return render(request, 'meta_review.html', args)

@@ -0,0 +1,115 @@
+import linecache
+import os
+
+from coala_utils.decorators import generate_eq
+
+
+@generate_eq('_filename', '_stamp')
+class FileFactory:
+    """
+    The FileFactory is a wrapper object to replace the actual file contents
+    from the file-dict. The object contains the following information about
+    the file:
+
+        * The filename (absolute file path).
+        * The parent directory the file is located in.
+        * The modification timestamp of the file.
+        * The file in the form of a string.
+        * The file in the form of a list.
+        * The file in binary format.
+
+    The equality of the object is checked just based on its filename and
+    timestamp.
+
+    To initialize a FileFactory object for a file:
+
+    >>> fp = FileFactory("./tests/io/FileFactoryTestFiles/test.txt")
+
+    Make the object into an iterable when required
+
+    >>> for line in fp:
+    ...     print(line)
+    This is a test file.
+    <BLANKLINE>
+
+    Retrieve a single line:
+
+    >>> fp.line(1)
+    'This is a test file.\\n'
+
+    Get all the lines in the file as a list:
+
+    >>> fp.lines
+    ('This is a test file.\\n',)
+    """
+
+    def __init__(self, filename):
+        """
+        :param filename:
+            The absolute filepath.
+        """
+        self._filename = os.path.abspath(filename)
+        self._parent = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(self._filename))
+        self._stamp = os.path.getmtime(self._filename)
+
+    def line(self, line):
+        """
+        :param line:
+            The line number from which the string is to be retrieved.
+        :return:
+            The retrieved string at the given line number from the file.
+        """
+        return linecache.getline(self._filename, line)
+
+    @property
+    def lines(self):
+        """
+        To get all the lines in the file in form of a list.

+from coala_utils.Comparable import Comparable
+
+
+class BaseTestHelper:
+    """
+    This is a base class for all Bears' tests of coala's testing API.
+    """
+
+    def assertComparableObjectsEqual(self, observed_result, expected_result):
+        """
+        Compares individual fields of the Result object and yields messages in
+        case of an attribute mismatch.
+        """
+        if len(observed_result) == len(expected_result):
+            messages = ''
+            for observed, expected in zip(observed_result, expected_result):
+                if (isinstance(observed, Comparable)
+                        and isinstance(expected, Comparable)) \
+                        and (type(observed) is type(expected)):
+                    for attribute in type(observed).__compare_fields__:
+                        try:
+                            assert getattr(observed, attribute) == \
+                                getattr(expected, attribute), \
+                                '{} mismatch: {}, {} != {}, {}'.format(
+                                    attribute,
+                                    observed.origin, observed.message,
+                                    expected.origin, observed.message)
+                        except AssertionError as ex:
+                            messages += (str(ex) + '\n\n')
+                else:
+                    assert observed_result == expected_result, '%s != %s' % \
+                        (observed_result, expected_result)
+            if messages:
+                raise AssertionError(messages)
+        else:

+class DictionaryTagger(object):

fields.body:
an extra level is needed in the abstraction, which needs to be a separate PR before this.
this isnt creating a meta bear.
A meta bear is like URLBear, which only yields HiddenResult.  See URLHeadBear and InvalidLinkBear for how they all link together.
We need a VCSCommitBear which only yields a CommitResult(HiddenResult).  SkipCIBear would then receive those CommitResult and only yield the CommitResult if the commit was a CI skip.
(and while trying to understand this, it is better to simply ignore GitCommitBear and HgCommitBear -- those will need to be glued back in after the redesign.)

+import os
+
+from coalib.parsing.Globbing import relative_recursive_glob
+from coala_utils.decorators import generate_eq
+
+
+@generate_eq('path')
+class Directory:
+    def __init__(self, path):
+        self._path = os.path.abspath(path)
+        self._parent = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(self._path))
+
+    def children(self):
+        elements = relative_recursive_glob(self._path, '**')
+        children = []
+
+        for e in elements:
+            children.append(e)
+
+        return children[1:]
+
